abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Education
            (Technical and Vocational Training) Project for Nepal was
            satisfactory. The project achieved its main objectives, its
            impact on institution building has been substantial, and
            both the Bank and the Borrower acted satisfactorily.
            However, sustainability is uncertain at this time. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, sustainable
            training programs require linkages to established industry,
            student counseling programs, and assistance in creating
            small enterprises and self-employment opportunities. Second,
            where major policy issues are beyond the control of a
            project, but central to its concept, suitable implementation
            arrangements need to be made. Third, serious problems and
            delays in construction and equipment can divert attention
            from wider issues of policy implementation under other
            components. Lastly, early identification and regular review
            of key project performance indicators can ensure balanced
            supervision and help highlight areas requiring particular attention.
